ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None.
Online office hours time.
The class was majorly a live discussion on our work and the concepts being explored in them; however, we did also have some days that were mainly lectures on graphic design elements.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Though this class doesn't center the Adobe Creative Cloud, I appreciated the focus on function rather than form (or whatever the correct phrase is). Don't get me wrong, you definitely learn software on-the-job if you're inclined to digitize your projects, but the purpose of this class is understanding graphic design, not InDesign or Illustrator.
Basic design principles, how to develop concepts and workflow for projects

I learned a lot about design principles through lectures and practice. I think learning fundamentals through abstract exercises (at the beginning) was helpful before transitioning into more long-term projects. Although there was not a lot of support for Adobe Suite and other programs, it was nice to have the option to explore using them.

Distinction between (and combination of) formal and conceptual characteristics of graphic design work, building a creative "workflow" to produce the work for class, how to deliver and receive critique, context of historical examples of graphic design, lots of practice producing work and having it critiqued.
I learned what graphic design actually is in terms of thinking about color, placement, balance, and much more.
Graphic design fundamentals (e.g. contrast, positive/negative space, visual rhythm). Typography and image relationships. Color theory and application. A bit of branding.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Though I REALLY appreciated how individualized the feedback was, the subjective nature of critique comments (a constantly-addressed elephant in the room) made it sometimes confusing to pair Henk's suggestions when they stand in opposition to your intent. With that said, I felt like Henk met all students where they were at with graphic design and I greatly appreciated this intention, given I was a newcomer myself.

Weaknesses: If the class has a lot of people, you don't get a lot of feedback because of time but you can always reach out to the professors on your own time. Wish the occasional lectures were more tailored to our course projects sometimes. 
Strengths: It's great to see your peers work and learn from them. You get a lot of one-on-one meetings with the professors. Also really enjoyed the guest speakers we got.

Prof van Assen and the TF (Nick) were definitely the highlights of the course. They were engaging and very helpful with feedback, but in and out of class. We spent a lot of time in class critiquing other students work, which was helpful but not as collaborative as it would have been in person. I would suggest reducing the course enrollment number in order to maximize the amount of time we got to listen to Prof van Assen lecture. I also would have liked more art theory and art history.

I really liked the format of the course and the emphasis on actually producing graphic design work. I also thought the focus (especially at the beginning) on hand work was really interesting and instructive.

I think it would be helpful to have more check-ins or something like that. Sometimes I felt like I was producing something in-line with the criteria of the assignment but at critique, I realized I missed the mark. I do not think this would happen so much in an in-person environment, because there would be opportunities to brainstorm with and see other people's works. Otherwise, I think more defined instructions would be helpful. I understand that creativity is key, and being told exactly what to do hinders the artistic process, but the constraints of a pandemic limit the ease of production.

Engaging and hands-on. I'm glad Illustrator and Photoshop were not required to succeed in this class--emphasis is on the basics. Group critiques were very valuable. A weakness is the workload was intense at times and quite intimidating. I also would have liked to see more slide presentations and lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The hardest thing about remote learning has been not being able to easily discuss with peers. We found using the chat function on Zoom was really helpful and class felt a lot more engaging once we started doing that .
I think that it was helpful to open up the chat during critiques in order to get more involvement from the class as a whole.
I think it was as good as it could have been given the circumstances.

This class went really well for being an art class focused on physical pieces that was taken online. The practice of students sharing their screens of photographed/scanned pieces and discussing with the class went well. It only really suffered when students did not have good access to the internet.
The progress check-ins and critiques were run well online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I think that Henk makes his expectations and the course format very clear in the first class, so if what he says sounds appealing to you, go for it! The class is very well structured and surprisingly worked very well in the online format. It was probably one of my favorite at Yale. It's a wonderful course, but it really helps if you're excited by it and see putting in the hours of work as fun. For me, the hours just flew by.

Yes if you want to learn some basic design thinking and see some really cool graphic design! Warning, you will not be learning about software so this is not your class for that. Also be prepared for the work.

I would! I do think students that are less familiar with Adobe programs will be at a slight disadvantage near the end of the course, but it's totally possible to do all the projects completely by hand. I think that the projects are designed well to challenge you and make you think outside of the box. By the end of the semester, you should have a strong and articulated portfolio. Also, Prof vA and the TF were amazing and so helpful.
Yes - if I thought they were serious enough about it that they would be willing to accept the workload.

If you are looking for a class to learn how to use digital graphic design programs, don't take this class! If you want to learn the elements and themes that you will be implementing through a digital program, or through physical means, take this class! It was a lot of work, but fun and rewarding, and the only way to get better at making art is to make art, which you will do a lot of in this class.

Yes, this course is a great start for someone with any interest in design. Even if you're not an art student, you learn to pay attention to detail and think more critically about design every where. A word of caution: in addition to the course fee, students will need to buy their own supplies (and some may not be fully used by the end of the course).
